Research Postgraduate Survival Guide1

Research Postgraduate Survival Guide1

Computer Science and Software Engineering
The University of Melbourne, October 2004


Contents

  • Welcome

Welcome

Welcome to the world of postgraduate studies in Computer Science and Software Engineering. It is a world full of excitement, challenge, and innovation, and it is our hope that you will enter it, thrive within it, and eventually emerge from it with the skills and enthusiasm to last a lifetime of employment in the discipline of computing, be it in industry or academia.

Being a postgraduate student is a form of apprenticeship, and supervising a postgraduate one of the most demanding of all teaching tasks. There are many hurdles to be crossed, and in every candidacy there will be setbacks that must be coped with, for both supervisor and student. This document is intended to answer some of the myriad of day-to-day questions that are the bane of the postgraduate student, and, perhaps, help some of those setbacks to be avoided. Postgraduate students--and their staff supervisors--are encouraged to read this document periodically. Suggestions for improvement are also welcome, and will be to the benefit of future post-graduates.

Note that this document is of an advisory nature only, and does not have the status of regulation. The Head of Department is directly answerable to the Vice-Chancellor for all activity within the department, including postgraduate affairs.

What to do next

The first few days and weeks of your candidature will be very confusing. You may find the following checklist helpful.

In your first day...

  1. Introduce yourself to Julien Reid, CSSE departmental office. Arrange office allocation, keys and key-card.
  2. Introduce yourself to Pinoo Bharucha, CSSE departmental office. Arrange photocopy card, get current copy of departmental ``Postgraduate Survival Guide'' and ``Postgraduate Handbook''.
  3. Arrange an entry in the departmental phone list. Arrange membership of the tea/coffee fund. Bring a different-looking mug for use in the department.
  4. Introduce yourself to Aaron Burnham (room 6.26), Ling Shi (6.24), or Wilson Afonso (6.18) and arrange computer access, accounts, and a password. (Accounts will only be issued to students who have confirmed their enrolment.) You will automatically be added to mailing lists such as cs-seminars and cs-postgrads. It is vital for you to be on cs-postgrads to receive pertinent information.
  5. Introduce yourself to your supervisor. Tell them your login id and office allocation. Arrange a first business meeting. Remind your supervisor that you will need a Safety Induction. This induction is usually run by the Safety Officer, Cindy Sexton, (cindy).

In your first week...

  1. Visit the School of Graduate Studies (SGS) in the 1888 Building. Browse the notice boards, investigate resources, pick up interesting brochures and have a look around. Visit the Postgraduate Association office and consider membership. The SGS administer the M.Sc. and Ph.D. degrees, so if you are enrolled in one of those, introduce yourself in the office, confirm your enrolment and obtain a current copy of the corresponding degree regulations. Ask them for a copy of the useful ``PhD Calendar''.
  2. Have a first business meeting with your supervisor. Get a bibliography of background papers. Start reading.
  3. Read the departmental ``Postgraduate Survival Guide'' and ``Postgraduate Handbook''.
  4. Establish your X-windows, editing, news, mail and world-wide web environments. Check that you can run LATEX and bibtex.
  5. Locate the departmental postgraduate notice board and browse the displays.
  6. Introduce yourself to the Postgraduate Coordinator, James Bailey, Room 4.21.
  7. Attend a postgrad seminar (Friday 12:00 noon, currently in Room 2.06 and a departmental seminar (normally Tuesday, 12:00 noon in Theatre 3).
  8. Attend a postgrad morning tea (Monday 13:30 in 5.08, sometimes also Friday 11:00 in Level 4 Staff Room). Introduce yourself to the other postgrads and indulge in some silliness. Check out what sort of activities they currently run (bridge, soccer,...).
  9. Introduce yourself to Thomas Weichert, Technical Services, Room 6.22. Get your picture taken for the departmental image collection.
  10. Visit and explore the Mathematical Sciences Library in the Richard Berry Building, the Engineering Library in the Old Engineering Building, the Baillieu Library, and the ERC (Education Resource Centre) Library.
  11. Visit the Student Union Building, and check out food and coffee outlets on campus and around University Square.

In your first month...

  1. Meet several times with your supervisor.
  2. In consultation with your supervisor, approach other staff to join your advisory committee (see Section 8). Inform Pinoo in the CSSE office of the composition of your committee when it is finalised.
  3. Arrange an initial meeting with your advisory committee.
  4. Produce a 3-5 page research outline (including a bibliography of possible resources) as a straw proposal to be discussed with your supervisor.
  5. Re-read the departmental ``Postgraduate Survival Guide'' and ``Postgraduate Handbook''.
  6. Look at the Postgraduate Group web site http://www.cs.mu.oz.au/pgrad, volunteer to take on a role.

In your first semester...

  1. Attend the Postgraduate Research Seminar Series, and do some writing.

And then, every year thereafter...

  1. Give a postgraduate seminar (and go to all the others).
  2. Take a pro-active role in postgraduate affairs. Initiate and support discussion/social activities.
  3. Write regularly; in consultation with your supervisor, consider submitting a paper to an appropriate venue.
  4. Meet at least twice with your full advisory committee to discuss progress and directions.
  5. M.Comp.Sc., M.Eng.Sc. and M.Sc. students: discuss with your supervisor and advisory committee the possibility of applying for conversion to Ph.D. candidature.
  6. Ph.D. students: discuss with your supervisor and advisory committee the need for a confirmation application.
  7. In either case, meet with your advisory committee and discuss your annual report.
  8. Re-read the departmental ``Postgraduate Survival Guide'', ``Postgraduate Handbook'', and the regulations governing the degree you are enrolled in.

People

Structure of the Department

There are three broad groups of staff in the department.

The academic staff undertake the public function of the department, the teaching and research. Academic staff also contribute in a variety of other ways, by sitting on University or Faculty committees; by participating in school curriculum design; by acting as external examiners for other departments; and by acting as consultants to business and industry.

In these endeavours the academic staff are supported by the office staff and the technical staff. The office staff provide an enormous amount of ``behind the scenes'' administrative support; the technical staff a commensurate amount of hardware and software support. The current office staff are Jon Callandar (Department Manager) Julien Reid (Administrative Manager), Pinoo Bharucha (Administrative Officer), Binh Phan (Administrative Assistant), Louise Walker (Undergraduate Programs Manager), Vanessa Smith (Academic Programs Officer), and Cindy Sexton (Safety Officer).

Postgraduate students are also an integral part of the department, and form a fourth important group. Without them the department could not function. It is important that students understand the role they play in the activities of the department, and they should be prepared to contribute--by organising social events and seminars; by participating in discussion on matters such as curriculum; by providing teaching support for undergraduate classes; and by providing a focus for the research activity of the department. As apprentice academics, postgraduate students can do much to create a lively, spirited, and productive environment.

All of the academic staff report directly to the Head of Department (Professor Rao Kotagiri, rao). Postgraduate students are managed as a group by the Postgraduate Coordinator (James Bailey, jbailey) and individually by their supervisors.

The supervisor

Of all of the staff, the most important to each postgraduate is their supervisor (or, in some cases, supervisors). In many cases the supervisor will become a friend as well as a colleague, and it is important that the right choice be made at the commencement of the candidature. It is relatively easy to change supervisor at the beginning of the candidature, but increasingly harder as the candidature progresses. Students who are unhappy with their supervisor should discuss the matter with the postgraduate coordinator at the earliest opportunity.

The supervisor should treat the student as a valued member of the department and as a research colleague. Through the good work of students the reputation of the supervisor is enhanced, and good research will inevitably lead to joint publication of research results, in many cases far more so than had the supervisor spent the equivalent amount of their own time working alone. Postgraduate students act as a multiplier, and should be welcomed and sought after by potential supervisors.

It is a general University policy that no staff member should be supervising more than seven full-time equivalent research students, including honours-level undergraduates. Moreover, this limit assumes that students are at different stages of their candidacy, as different demands are placed upon the supervisor at different times. The upper limit of seven EFTSU is enforced by the postgraduate selection committee, and prospective students should be aware that supervisors may at times be fully committed and unable to accept further students.

A large amount of written material is available about the student-supervisor relationship, and how it can be established soundly to the benefit of both parties. One such document (``How to be a Good Graduate Student/Graduate Student Advisor'') is attached to the print version of this document. It is also possible for supervisors to attend ``Supervision of Postgraduate Students'' courses at the Centre for the Study of Higher Education. Indeed, students might reasonably ask their supervisor when last they attended such a course.

The advisory committee

In addition to a primary supervisor each student will be assigned a non-technical advisory committee to monitor their progress and provide non-technical assistance. The structure of these committees is described in Section 8 below.

Communication

Representatives for the postgraduate students meet occasionally with senior staff to canvass general postgraduate issues. Such meetings will usually be advertised in advance by mail, together with an invitation for agenda items.

The department has regular staff meetings, where various organisational and academic matters are discussed. Postgraduates are represented at these meetings by one or two students (who are periodically voted in at CSSEPG meetings when the positions become vacant). The postgraduate members can raise issues on behalf of students, and are also present to provide the postgraduate perspective on issues that may arise. They may communicate with the CSSEPG president on matters arising from these meetings that may be relevant to postgraduate students in general. If you have any issues or concerns, contact Gavin Baker (gavinb), Room 3.25a, phone 8344-1424.

Students may at any time seek appointments with the postgraduate coordinator or, for serious matters, the Head of Department.

Facilities

Safety

All post-graduate students must undergo a safety induction. This is usually performed by the Safety Officer, Cindy Sexton, but it is the responsibility of your supervisor to make sure that it happens. Read our building's Safety Manual (follow the link from http://www.dis.unimelb.edu.au/EHS/) and get to know its safety rules and evacuation routes. If you identify a hazardous situation in or around the building, please notify Vicki Jackson (8344-1507), the Building Emergency Controller. Also read the section about occupational overuse syndrome (OOS) or repetitive strain injury (RSI) at http://www.engr.unl.edu/ee/eeshop/rsi.html, and evaluate your work practices in light of this information. Adjusting bad posture and typing practice now could well save you an immense amount of problems later.

Building facilities

The ICT building includes a wide range of facilities. There are many meeting rooms for small groups of people. These rooms may be booked by students for work-related meetings. There are also smaller seminar rooms, usually used for fourth year lectures. These may be used for meetings of up to about 20 people. Booking is online through http://www.cs.mu.oz.au/roombooking/.

The building contains a number of tutorial rooms and lecture theatres. These may also be booked for student use, but semester-time usage is normally very high. The administration of these rooms is through the central room bookings system, and so considerable lead time (at least a week) is normally required. The office will make the necessary contact with central reservations; contact Julien in the first instance.

Postgraduate office allocations are handled by Julien, in consultation with the supervisor of each student. Julien also handles key-cards and office keys; new students should, upon arrival, present themselves to Julien to arrange these housekeeping details. A deposit is usually required for all keys issued; this will be returned when students hand back their keys at the completion of their degree.

Research postgraduate students can use the level 4 staff room and the small tea-making rooms around the building.

Parking

Students are not entitled to daytime parking permits unless there are medical reasons. Public parking is available at the University Square car park. Enter either from Berkeley Street, or from Bouverie Street. After-hours parking is permitted; students may purchase a yearly after-hours parking permit from the Traffic Office near the Richard Berry Building. Contact the Traffic Office for further details.

Working hours

The usual working hours (that is, hours of unrestricted access to the building) are nominally 9am to 5pm, Monday to Friday. There is no restriction on work outside these hours, but students are cautioned that approximately 40 hours per week of research-related study is required, and that the key to achieving this is regular working hours. Tutoring duties, and other outside interests such as sport and social clubs, should not be considered to be part of the ``business'' of being a postgraduate student.

Four weeks annual leave is permitted each year, but students should consult with their supervisor before taking the leave. Absence through illness of less than a week does not require a doctor's certificate, but longer illness should be substantiated by medical evidence. Holders of scholarships should note any leave conditions that apply to their awards.

Emergencies

Students should familiarise themselves with emergency procedures. Any emergency should be reported to Security on extension 46666. Building related emergencies should be notified to Maintenance, or by using extension 46000.

Security

There have been regular thefts of personal belongings and departmental equipment from the building. There is also a risk of arson or other malicious damage, which could destroy large amounts of research effort. To minimise these undesirable events, all members of the department are asked to observe a few simple precautions:

  • Keep all room doors locked when the room is not occupied by a person who is in a position to observe the entry from all doors of casual or unauthorised visitors. Ensure that all doors into corridors are left locked at lunch time.

  • Never prop open doors, or leave doors unlocked, to ``let in friends''. Similarly, do not let into the building people who purport to be ``the friends of Fred''.

  • Question all strangers you see in the building, particularly at lunch time or after 5pm, or at the weekend. If you notice unusual activities in the department let the General Office staff know immediately. Outside normal hours ring the Security Office on extension 46666 (for urgent assistance/advice 24 hours). Students should avoid confrontational situations with unwanted ``guests'', as this is the job of the Security Office. Students should phone the Security Advice line on extension 44674 to arrange an after-hours ``escort'' to parked cars or tram stops.

  • Regularly check over the contents of your office. If any unexpected disappearance of equipment is observed, report the matter immediately to your supervisor or another staff member. Prompt reporting of theft is necessary for insurance reasons.

  • When leaving your office at the end of the day, turn off the lights and lock all doors. When leaving the building after normal hours, if the outside door has been locked, make sure that it closes properly after you.
Your personal items are not covered by University insurance. You can usually add items such as laptops and bicycles to your home contents insurance.

Alcohol may not be brought into the department without the express permission of the Head of Department.

Computing facilities

The department has a diverse computer network, based on UNIX servers supporting about 600 client machines. Furthermore, the department provides internet access, dial-in access, file backup, network printing, system administration and technical support services. The computer network supports TCP/IP at 100 Mbps. The department network is connected to the University's network via Gigabit ethernet, and subsequently to the internet. Details are available at http://www.cs.mu.oz.au/systems/.

Most file systems, including /home/pgrad/ are mounted on all general-purpose departmental machines. Research students are also allocated accounts on mulga.cs.mu.oz.au, which is the main mail machine. Students wishing to receive their mail on the (undergraduate) mail server queeg.cs.mu.oz.au will need to place a .forward in their mulga account. Students requiring access to any special equipment should, in the first instance, discuss the need with their supervisor.

The default equipment provided for full-time postgraduate students is a desk with a colour X-terminal. Postgraduate students have equivalent access as staff to the servers, and related services, such as email, newsgroups, printing and dial-up modems.

Students are required to exercise reasonable care to safeguard their accounts from break-in, and to protect the equipment in general from damage. Students who are detected attempting to crack the system or the accounts of other users will be dealt with according to the University discipline regulations. Students should appreciate that the equipment must be used collaboratively, and should refrain from activities that affect the ability of others to use the resources. What might seem like a harmless prank--sending forged mail, for example--can often have serious consequences. University policy is that computers and network equipment may only be used for University related business. In particular, offensive images must not be copied, stored, or viewed on any departmental computers.

Students must be aware that software is subject to copyright, and that all software installed onto any of the systems, whether for public or private use, must be correctly licensed. Do not download copyrighted songs, movies, or other non-study related material.

Getting started

You may be allocated an X-terminal or a PC running Windows 2000 or XP. An X-terminal will be connected to one of the servers. From a PC you will log on using the samba server.

To get started, copy the ``generic'' files from /local/share/skel/common on mundroo. This directory contains the files (bash_profile, cshrc, login, twmrc, and xrdb, and probably others as well) which can be copied to your home directory to names with . in front (e.g. .bash_profile, .cshrc) and then be edited as appropriate.

For text processing most staff and students use LATEX. A simple document to get started may be found on mundroo in ~alistair/latex.starter/sample.tex. Introductory classes in the use of LATEX are often run as part of the honours year; for details contact the Honours Coordinator (currently Les Kitchen, ljk). The CSSEPG's wiki at http://www.cs.mu.oz.au/pgrad/pgwiki/ also has pointers to LATEX resources. But it is probably a good idea to buy a LATEX book rather than rely on word of mouth expertise. Good books are LATEX: A Document Preparation System, Second Edition, Leslie Lamport, Addison-Wesley, The LATEX Companion, Michael Goossens, Frank Mittelbach, and Alexander Samarin, Addison-Wesley, and The LATEX Graphics Companion, Michael Goossens, Sebastian Rahtz, and Frank Mittelbach. The corresponding bibliography maintenance program is called bibtex, and users of LATEX should also familiarise themselves with the use of bibtex.

Mail addresses are of the form user@cs.mu.oz.au. Some useful mail aliases include cs-postgrads, cs-honours, cs-academics, cs-everyone, and cs-seminars. When replying to the originator of mail sent to a mailing list, be sure to remove the Cc: line from your reply. Failure to do so can lead to considerable embarrassment.

A variety of departmental information can be found at http://www.cs.mu.oz.au/.

Problems

The Department has an on-line system for dealing with the technical problems that invariably occur. Requests for help with accounts and computers should be lodged via http://www.cs.mu.oz.au/systems/rt.html. For information about what to include in requests, contact details and methods, see http://www.cs.mu.oz.au/systems/contact.html.

The world wide web

The web and web browsers offer an enormous range of information. For the uninitiated, start with the command 

    netscape www.cs.mu.oz.au/
at an X-terminal, and then follow your nose. A great deal of relevant student information can be found through http://www.unimelb.edu.au/ and http://www.sgs.unimelb.edu.au/. Many conference proceedings and other reports are available via the net. See, for example, the sites http://arxiv.org/archive/cs/intro.html and http://www.nzdl.org/. Citeseer, at http://citeseer.ist.psu.edu/cs/ gives access to a vast amount of computer science papers, and provides a citation index. Buddy, at
    http://xena.lib.unimelb.edu.au/cgi-bin/buddy.user
is the University's portal to all the online reference materials and digital libraries that we subscribe to, including large amounts of full-text literature. A good web indexer is Google at http://www.google.com/.

The Department is charged for the volume of its internet traffic. Internet traffic is one of the major costs of the Department each year. Please be sensible when browsing--file transfers that are not for ``University business'' are chargeable directly to the user, and even large network volumes that are for University use may need to be defended.

A short guide on how to set up your own web page can be found near the bottom of http://www.cs.mu.oz.au/systems/web.html. Thomas Weichert (tw) in Technical Services will arrange for capture of an image of you as a smiling happy postgrad.

Sensible work practices

A document on Repetitive Strain Injury is accessible through http://www.engr.unl.edu/ee/eeshop/rsi.html. It contains a number of pointers to other sources of information.

Use of University computing and network facilities

The relevant University statute can be found at http://www.unimelb.edu.au/ExecServ/Statutes/r81r7.htm.

Use of laptops in the building

The ICT building is provided with many ethernet ports and a wireless wavelan radio for connection to the network by staff and postgraduates. To use this system, you must register your hardware MAC address with the system. Then you can plug in to any of the ports in the building or make a wireless LAN connection. The site for registration is http://www.cs.mu.oz.au/register/.

Dial-up access

The Department provides modem access to CSSE machines. For details and instructions for use, see

    http://www.cs.mu.oz.au/local/tech/modems.html

Telephone and facsimile facilities

Most postgraduate offices are equipped with telephones. These may be used for incoming calls of a personal nature; however the University stipulates that outgoing calls should be business. All long distance calls should be organised through the office. The departmental phone number (for the office) is +61383441300. University phone numbers (834 prefix) may all be dialled as five-digit extension numbers without making use of an outside line. A departmental phone list can be found at

    http://www.cs.mu.oz.au/phone_pd_b/interface/ViewList.php
Please make sure that you notify the departmental office of your office and phone numbers when you first arrive, and when you move offices thereafter, so that the list can be kept up to date.

There is a facsimile machine in the office that may be used for business communication. The number is +61393481184. See the departmental office if you wish to send a fax.

Photocopying facilities

A photo copier is available in Room 4.11. Postgraduate students may be issued with an account for the photocopier upon commencement, see Pinoo in the office. Initial credit will be 1000 copies. Reasonable business use of the copier is supported by the department; overly frequent rechargings (more than once or twice a year) may result in the supervisor or student being asked to account for usage.

The photocopier may also be used for private use, and 5c per sheet of paper should be paid to the office.

To make overhead projector transparencies, contact the departmental office. Note: use of the wrong film in the copier can cause major damage. Do not use any films other than those issued by the office; and make it perfectly clear when you are asking that you will be using the film in the copier.

The office staff have absolute priority over the use of the department's photocopiers, and may preempt anyone at anytime.

The University policy on copyright is pinned to the wall adjacent to the photocopier; please observe it.

Printing

The department has a wide range of printing facilities. An introduction can be found in

    http://www.cs.mu.oz.au/systems/printing.html

Stationery

A small range of commonly used stationery items is provided in the departmental office. These are for business use only. Students may not, for any purposes, use University letterhead paper. This includes the common case when undergraduate students ask postgraduate tutors for references.

All other stationery supplies are administered by the departmental office. Students are expected to provide their own pens and notebooks.

Printer paper is available from the departmental office. When a printer runs out of paper and there is none nearby, common sense says that you should fetch several reams, not just one. Please keep the printer environments clean and tidy.

Unwanted printer paper should be recycled, and cartons are placed near most of the printers for this purpose. Students are also encouraged to use the reverse side of such paper for notes. On the other hand, one-side-used paper should only be loaded into the printer trays if you are sure that your job is next in the queue and if you promise both to remove the extra sheets from the printer tray after your job completes and to clear any paper jams that may result in your job not completing. The best way to minimise paper usage is through the use of the programs such as a2ps, psnup, and mpage. Manual pages for these may be found on mundroo.

Postal facilities

External mail should be organised through the departmental office. Mail of a business nature--paper submission is an obvious example--will be paid by the department. Private mail may be despatched through the department, but the correct value of postage must be affixed.

School of Graduate Studies

The School of Graduate Studies (SGS) was established in 1993 to oversee all postgraduate research programmes, and to administer the Ph.D. degree (the Ph.D. is a degree of the University rather than of any particular faculty). It is located in the 1888 building, opposite the northern end of Bouverie Street. The School also handles scholarships, both within the University and as a focal point for information about scholarships elsewhere. The SGS also provides study facilities, computer equipment, and publishing facilities for postgraduates. The University of Melbourne Postgraduate Association (UMPA) is also housed in the SGS. Students are encouraged to visit the 1888 building and examine the wide range of resources offered by these two organisations. Finally, the SGS also acts as a meeting place, providing interdisciplinary seminars and social events for postgraduate students.

The Postgraduate Bistro is open for extended hours, and offers a reasonably-priced venue for meals and snacks at all times of the day.

Housing

The University no longer guarantees students accommodation, but does offer a service for matching students to appropriate types of accommodation through Student Support Services (http://www.services.unimelb.edu.au/).

All commencing international students can apply for accommodation through a Priority Placement scheme, which favours early applicants. A new program for rural students also exists, which helps rural students with the skills to search for suitable housing.

Students can apply for housing directly through the internet via

    http://www.services.unimelb.edu.au/housing/

Library facilities

Melbourne's University Library provide traditional services including loans, reference, interlibrary loans, and online searching. Most services are available without charge to enrolled students and staff of the University of Melbourne for purposes of teaching, study and research. Exceptions are the charges made for interlibrary loans and the printing of full-text from online collections. The library also participates in the CAVAL Reciprocal Borrowing Program, and you may enrol as borrower (by getting a CAVAL card) at other participating libraries in Victoria. Your student card gives you access to all the local resources.

At the start of each semester the Engineering Library runs introductory courses on the use of library facilities and online research tools. If you have not had such an introduction, check with the library when the next session is run, or ask your Postgraduate Coordinator to arrange a short course.

At least four of the branch libraries are of interest to students and researchers in Computer Science and Software Engineering:

  • The Engineering Library is located on the first floor of the Old Engineering Building.
  • The Mathematical Sciences Branch Library (MSBL) is located on the ground floor of the Richard Berry Building.
  • The Education Resource Centre (ERC) Library is located behind the School of Graduate Studies.
  • The Baillieu Library is located on the western side of the main campus.
The Engineering Library is our ``home'' library, and most of the new monographs acquired for our discipline end up there. Also, a great many Computer Science serials come to the Engineering Library, including all IEEE publications. If a request cannot be handled online via the University's web pages (http://www.lib.unimelb.edu.au/), then you would normally go to the see the friendly staff at the Engineering Library.

The MSBL was originally run and funded jointly by the Departments of Mathematics, Statistics, and Computer Science, without support from the University Library. Around 1990, the library became part of the University Library, and the collection was recorded in the University Library's catalogue. MSBL is of great importance for Computer Science and Software Engineering, as it holds the largest collection of journals, many conference proceedings, and the series Lecture Notes in Computer Science. All serials published by the Association for Computing Machinery end up in MSBL.

The ERC has extensive collections, not only in the area of education. Of interest to us are its special collections in the areas of mathematics and logic.

The Baillieu Library has a few Computer Science Journals and an extensive older collection in areas related to theoretical computer science, such as logic and computability.

You can access the University Library's catalogue browsers, such as the Innopac system, from your terminal. You can also view your borrowing record and renew loans, all via http://www.lib.unimelb.edu.au/. To use the library's extensive electronic resources, go to http://subjectresources.infodiv.unimelb.edu.au/, find `Engineering' and click `Computer Science and Software Engineering'. You may want to bookmark the page you arrive at. If you click `Key Resources' you will get to a portal for useful discipline-specific resources, including indexes such as Web of Science and Citeseer, and full-text archives such as digital libraries from the ACM, IEEE, and various publishers. To access some of these you will be asked to provide the barcode number from your student card.

Because of space shortage, not all print resources are on shelves in the branch libraries. Some older material, such as old volumes of Lecture Notes in Computer Science, and some journals, are kept in storage (for example, CARM, which is in Bundoora). You can order this material, but expect that it will take 4-5 days to arrive.

Casual employment

Students interested in employment as tutors, demonstrators, and lab supervisors, should see http://www.cs.mu.oz.au/tcsbs/. Note that the regulations for most degrees, and for most scholarships, place limits upon the amount of outside work that may be undertaken. Students should also be aware that casual work can be a drain on their time and a distraction from their study. Nevertheless, tutoring an undergraduate class is an important part of the academic apprenticeship, and postgraduate students are encouraged to undertake such duties. Workshops on teaching techniques are organised from time to time, and postgraduates are urged to attend. For details of these workshops contact Michael Kirley (castute).

Senior postgraduate students who believe that they will follow an academic career path may also be invited to take responsibility for writing and delivery of a small number of lectures in main stream undergraduate subjects. Such teaching experience will stand them in good stead when applying for academic teaching/research positions. Students wishing to be considered for such offers should make themselves known to Steven Bird (sb).

Seminars

Seminars form an important part of your Computer Science education. All postgraduate students are therefore expected to attend most advertised seminars in the Departmental and Postgraduate series.

Tuesday seminars

These are the ``mainline'' seminars--guest speakers from outside the department with varied content. The usual time is 12:00 noon, and the usual place is Theatre 3 (Room 2.05). The coordinator is Rajkumar Buyya (raj). Information on current seminars can be found at

    http://www.cs.mu.oz.au/info/seminars

Friday seminars

One departmental requirement is that all postgraduate students present a seminar each twelve months; this requirement is catered for in the Friday seminar stream. Usual time is 12:00 noon, usual place is Room 2.06. The coordinators at the time of writing are Chee Shin Yeo (csyeo) and Srikumar Venugopal (srikumar). Information can be found at

    http://www.cs.mu.oz.au/pgrad/seminars/

Other meetings

Most of the research groups in the department have their own regular meeting times at which talks are sometimes presented. Depending on their interests, students may also find regular attendance at these of benefit. These talks are usually not widely advertised, and students should enquire through their supervisor about being entered onto the appropriate mailing list.

Other departments

The Department of Information Systems and the Department of Computer Science at RMIT also host a variety of seminars. Students are encouraged to attend these when they are of interest.

School of Graduate Studies

The SGS organises seminars from time to time. These are generally chosen to be of wide interest, and students are encouraged to attend these seminars and participate in the wider activities of the school with their peers from other academic departments.

Research

There is a wide range of literature available that describes the research process, and mechanisms that can be employed to ensure that research degrees are approached in a professional and ultimately successful manner. The SGS and UMPA both offer guidance in this area; another document (``How to be a good graduate student/graduate student advisor'') is attached to the print version of this document.

In all of this literature there are a few key themes that appear to be central to a successful candidature, and these are summarised in this section.

Start early

The clock starts ticking from the first day, and never runs backwards. By the end of the degree, with a submission deadline looming and a scholarship about to expire, most students wish they could have back some of those lazy summer days of three years before when the major pressure in each day was to make the appropriate bridge bid. The fraction of students that have their thesis finished and ready to submit on the first day of their submission window is vanishingly small.

Be organised

Organise your time, and regard yourself as being employed. Work regular hours. Set yourself deadlines, and stick to them. Find a filing cabinet that you can call your own, and use it. Make use of a notebook to record plans, dreams, and frustrations. Writing, even if it is only for your own private consumption, is a sure way to identify opportunities and weaknesses. Indeed, writing is sufficiently important that the whole of the next section is devoted to it.

Write notes on papers you read, and record them into your bibliography immediately. Spending the last two weeks of thesis writing tracking down page or volume numbers for papers you wish to cite is very frustrating.

Talk to your supervisor

Supervisors can be elusive, and students reluctant to pin them down and insist on meetings. This can be very wasteful. When you want to talk to your supervisor, don't be fobbed off by a ``ok, lets do that next week'' answer. Fix a time for today or tomorrow.

A good supervisor will also pursue students and demand meetings, but this is often hard to keep up if the student is evasive or habitually brings nothing new to meetings. Most supervisors can easily fill their days with other useful activities, and the research programme of each student they supervise is only a small part of the supervisor's spectrum of responsibilities. Students do not have this opportunity to timeslice, since they often have only one active process. Entering the ``wait-state'' is counter-productive.

Meetings might be as often as a few minutes every day, or as infrequent as an hour once a month. The need for meetings will also change as the candidacy progresses. But, without some appropriate level of support from and interaction with their supervisor, most students will become non-productive and dis-enchanted.

If it reaches the stage where either party finds that they are relieved when meetings are cancelled, or cancellation/postponement is a regular occurrence, then the matter should be brought to the attention of the postgraduate coordinator.

Keep a record

Supervision meetings should be documented, with an agreed list of actions and deadlines exchanged after each. This documentation should also include the agreed time for the next meeting. In the discipline of computing, the desired record is easily achieved by, during the last few minutes of each meeting, jointly composing some electronic mail that both parties can retain a copy of. A notebook serves just as well. Such a record makes it easy to see whether or not the work is progressing as planned and whether progress is being made. It is also an important backup in the unlikely event of some subsequent dispute arising over the performance of either of the two parties.

Experimental work should also be well-documented. Retain the output of old experimental runs (including a record of what parameters were set, and what data file was being used, and what machine you were running on, and etc etc) and old versions of your programs in a carefully organised and well-documented way. You never know when you might want to further test something that you thought was finished with. One obvious case is when a paper is 12 months in the refereeing process, and a reviewer comes back to you and asks for another column of values in a table, or for clarification of what the experimental data was.

Deal with difficulties

The unpleasant things are the hardest to do, so we put them off. Don't. If some issue is a potential problem, the earlier it is resolved the sooner the research programme can be returned to. Big problems rarely emerge fully grown; they develop out of small problems. Small problems should be dealt with as they arise.

Writing

The essence of scholarship is writing. An academic--student or staff--must regard dissemination of their research results as being of the utmost importance, and should concentrate their efforts accordingly. For a student, the goal is to produce a thesis. But it is also expected that along the way students will have authored shorter works--technical reports and papers. Indeed, the earlier a student falls into the habit of writing, the more likely it is that they will bring their candidacy to a timely and successful conclusion. Writing includes the taking of notes on seminar speakers, summarising papers read, describing experiments undertaken and hypotheses formed, and the authoring of surveys, tutorials, and annotated bibliographies. Regular writing is the key to thesis success, and the importance of this simple act cannot be stressed enough.

Technical reports

A technical report describes newly completed work, or work still under way. It is often the prelude to more formal publication, and, except for unusual cases, should not be regarded as an end in itself. The exceptions are when the technical report contains reference material that might otherwise be unpublishable, such as an extensive bibliography, or a manual for a software system. Except for such cases, it is expected that more formal publication--in conference proceedings and then, ultimately, in archival form in a journal of record--will be pursued.

The departmental technical report series has been terminated. If you wish to make available unpublished work you can either organise it to be available through your homepage, or if you want to have it widely accessible and date stamped, you can place it in an archive like CoRR at http://arxiv.org/archive/cs/intro.html.

Students are required to have the approval of their supervisor before publishing (even in their own web site) a technical report including their supervisor as author, and are suggested to do the same even if the supervisor is not an author. The work reflects on the reputation of the department as a whole as well as that of the authors, and supervisors should act as referees to guard this reputation. Authors should also consider approaching external experts for opinions before finalising the contents of technical reports.

The department does not have a policy on the question of on-line access to technical reports. On one hand, there is clearly a case for making PostScript (or even LATEX source) for reports available on the net--we all benefit from open access to a wide variety of information, including the technical reports of other people. However there is also an argument in favour of confidentiality. Proponents of non-open access argue that the essence of ``publishing'' is exclusivity, and that in making material available via the net, authors are effectively preempting the traditional publication process. They conclude that publishers might quite legitimately refuse to accept an otherwise good-quality paper that has been net-published if the author is unable to transfer an exclusive copyright to the publishing house. For an extended exposition of this viewpoint, see the article in the April 1995 Communications of the ACM on the matter. The ACM recently relaxed their rather strict viewpoint, and now allow limited electronic dissemination of in-submission papers, see http://www.acm.org/pubs/copyright_policy/for further details.

In an ideal world we would not require or seek the intervention of publishers, and this is why there are so many useful Web pages available. The world is, however, not ideal, and academics rely upon formal publication of their work for appointment, promotion, and research grant purposes. One sensible compromise is to ``publish'' a textual abstract of technical reports and submitted papers as a web page and inviting interested parties to enter into email or postal correspondence to obtain a full (paper or electronic) copy of the document. This has the advantage of advertising the work to the net-community at large, but, because the dissemination of the copies is controlled, not affecting the eventual desire to transfer copyright to a publisher. Parties who receive electronic copies after an explicit request will usually agree to some form of limiting behaviour. For example, it is not unreasonable to mail people PostScript of your work, but request them to delete the file immediately upon printing it.

Writing papers

More formal presentation of some piece of work is achieved by submitting a paper for publication. In computing the usual forum for presentation of new results is at a conference; such presentation establishes a ``place-holder'' in the community, which should, in most specialisations, be followed up by a ``journal version'' of the paper in which all proofs are complete, all experimental results explained, and all feedback, queries, and criticisms (from readers of the conference version) accounted for. Only when innovative work is described in a journal paper should it be deemed to be ``completed'' and ``on the record''.

For students, the long turnaround time from initial submission to final publication (as long as two, three, or four year) makes journal papers hard to achieve. Conference papers have faster turnaround, usually about six months from submission to ``publication'', but the refereeing process is more variable, and the distribution of the proceedings often quite limited. Thus, it is often the case that conference papers are prepared during the candidacy, and journal papers after thesis submission. (Some scholarships offer the opportunity of ``writing-up'' extensions after thesis submission. Contact the SGS for details.)

For a resource list to the writing/research process, see

    http://www.cs.cmu.edu/afs/cs.cmu.edu/user/mleone/web/how-to.html
A discipline-specific book on writing is Writing for Computer Science: The Art of Effective Communication, Justin Zobel, Springer, 1997. A very detailed book on scholarly writing, with emphasis on correct citation, references and format, is A Handbook for Scholars, Mary-Claire van Leunen, Oxford University Press, 1992. You should at the very least browse books such as these at an early stage of your candidature.

Conferences

Consequent upon acceptance of a paper at a conference is the need for at least one of the authors to attend that conference. Note that if no author plans to attend, the paper should not have been submitted, and submission is an implicit undertaking that if the paper is accepted, at least one author will attend. Discuss the issue of attendance--and funding to cover the cost of that attendance--before submitting the paper.

Attendance at the right conferences is an important component of the research process. It is at conferences that one hears of new developments in other research groups that have not yet even been written up; that one meets potential employers; and that one can be exposed to the research work of others, which will inevitably provide new insights to the benefit of one's own project. Conferences also provide extensive opportunity for social interaction with one's colleagues, and this is increasingly important as more and more research activity takes place through the wonders of the Internet. It is not at all unusual to co-author papers with people that you have never met; nevertheless, such collaborations are cemented by face to face meetings.

Attendance at the wrong conferences is a waste of time and money. Don't submit papers to conferences just because they are in interesting locations or near your family; and in particular don't put together a paper and send it to a conference just because you received what appears to be a personalised invitation to submit work. Aim for the very best conferences, and ignore the never-ending stream of third-rate events that accept third-rate papers. Remember always that a publication record is judged on quality more than on quantity; and one paper in a recognised international journal or first-class conference counts for five wishy-washy ones. The litmus test to apply is always this: ``Will a copy of the work automatically make it back to the University library?'' If the answer is ``no'', chances are that the people you would like to see your work--similar-minded people at other institutions who rely on their library for support--will remain oblivious of it, and you have wasted your time.

Nevertheless, introducing a student to their network of colleagues is one of the most important tasks a supervisor must perform, and conferences are the ideal venue for this. With this in mind, early in the candidature supervisor and student should identify the important conferences for the speciality, and make long-term plans for submission of papers and for attendance.

Travel on university business

Postgraduate students who plan to travel overseas on University-related business must first refer to the University's Risk Management Office web page at http://www.unimelb.edu.au/rmo/and read the section ``Travelling and Working Off Campus''. Follow the links to the University's Overseas Travel Policy and to DFAT's travel advice, which groups countries into ``risk categories''. Also read the information on off-campus activity at

    http://www.unimelb.edu.au/ehsm/7.html#7.1
This mentions forms which need to be completed. These forms should be collected from the CSSE General Office and be completed in consultation with your supervisor:
  1. A Guideline Form for Off Campus Travel and Work Policy (to assess risks of the trip and to confirm that you have read the Travel Policy).
  2. If there are risks involved with your health, mode of travel, the activity, or the location (for example, you plan to travel to a Risk Category 2 or 3 country), you will also need to complete Risk Assessment 2D Model Form. Travel to countries in Risk Category 1 is not permitted.
  3. Medical Questionnaire for Off Campus Activities (Optional). This asks whether you have any medical/physical conditions which could affect your safe participation in the activity you are undertaking.
  4. Overseas Travel Vaccination Guidelines (if applicable).
You also need to lodge:
  1. Details of activity (for example, conference), location, and your contact details, so that you can be contacted in case the University issues a recall of students from the country you are visiting.
Forms should be submitted for approval well in advance of your travel. Students must have travel insurance, which can be arranged through the University Risk Management Office or via another agency.

When you return from travel you will need to lodge a travel diary. This is to meet the requirements of the Australian Taxation Office. (For travel within Australia, a diary is only required if you are away for more than five nights.) The diary should provide the following for each business activity:

  • the date the entry was made;
  • the place where the activity was undertaken;
  • the date and approximate time when the activity commenced;
  • the duration of the activity;
  • the nature of the activity;
  • costs associated with activity.
You can get a copy of the travel diary format from the office, or you can just keep a record sheet in your own format, or supply a copy of your own diary. The diary should have your signature on it. A detailed travel itinerary that includes the above details (except, of course, the costs) prepared before the trip is an acceptable travel diary, provided that a staff member endorses that it was followed or records any variations that occurred.

Travel support

In recognition of the importance of conference attendance, the department, where possible, supports student attendance at conferences. Certain conditions, however, need to be satisfied:

  • The paper or poster is a fully refereed publication (DETYA F1 category).
  • You will be presenting the paper or poster.
  • You will present the research in the Postgraduate seminar series.
  • You did not receive similar support within the last 12 months.
  • You have tried to package the conference trip with some other professional visit.
To apply for travel support, you should
  • Obtain a Melbourne Abroad Travel Scholarship application form from http://www.services.unimelb.edu.au/scholarships/pgrad/travelling/matss.html
  • Fill it out as far as possible (some questions relate to whether departmental support has been given).
  • Attach proof of acceptance and full refereeing of the publication (usually the acceptance email with referee reports).
  • Attach date of Departmental or Postgraduate seminar series presentations (which may be in the future).
  • Place in an envelope in the Postgraduate Coordinator's mail box.
At the time of writing, support is limited to AUD 1500 for travel and registration. PhD students are advised to also apply for SGS Melbourne Abroad Travelling Scholarship funding (the application will be returned for this purpose).

Students should also seek funding from their supervisor or research group. In fact, you should discuss with your supervisor a financial plan for attending a conference before submitting a paper, so that the embarrassing case, of having to withdraw an accepted paper since nobody can attend to present, does not occur.

Authorship

One question that sometimes becomes vexatious when written work is being prepared is that of authorship. In general, published work that is generated during the course of a postgraduate degree will usually be as a result of joint intellectual effort and so will be jointly authored by student and supervisor. It will often be the case that the student has undertaken the bulk, if not all, of the ``chore'' of capturing some idea on paper and creating the actual document that describes that idea; and it might also be the case that they have undertaken all of the implementation and experimentation phases of the investigation. Nevertheless, it is also usually true that the supervisor has substantially contributed to the conception of the investigation and given ongoing advice as to its execution. It is thus usual for supervisor and student to share the credit for the work, especially during the early stages of candidacy, with the ordering of the authors reflecting the extent to which the two parties contributed to the work.

There may also be cases in which sole authorship, or joint authorship amongst a group of students is appropriate. This might occur during the latter stages of a candidacy when the student can be expected to be in contact with other experts in the field. Nevertheless, all involved supervisors should be consulted prior to submission; and it may be that further improvements in the quality of the submitted paper are the result of such consultation. Disputes over authorship should be raised with the postgraduate coordinator or the Head of Department if they cannot be resolved amicably in this way.

For their part, supervisors should read drafts of papers promptly, provide input as to presentation and style, and write components of the paper as appropriate. Notwithstanding any of the suggestions made above, supervisors are expected to collaborate with their student co-authors in the same cooperative manner as they would with staff co-authors. Moreover, co-authorship must always be a return for a genuine contribution to the intellectual property embodied in a paper, and simply being the supervisor of a postgraduate student, or being responsible in some way for generating the research funding that supports that student, is, of itself, certainly not a reason for research work undertaken by the student to be attributed jointly.

See also the relevant sections of the University Code of Conduct for Research which is available at http://www.unimelb.edu.au/ExecServ/Statutes/r171r8.htm.

Approval

All submissions for publication should be approved by the supervisor. Similarly, supervisors should not submit papers based upon work undertaken by a student without the approval of the student, even if the student is listed as a co-author. In rare cases it may be that student and supervisor disagree over the worth of some piece of written work (be it sole or joint authorship); in this case the dispute should be referred to the postgraduate coordinator, who will seek further input and make a recommendation to the Head of Department.

Presenting a paper

This is an important task, and should not be taken lightly. One very helpful document can be found via

    http://hercule.csci.unt.edu/ian/guides/guides.html
It is most important that a practice talk be given to a small group of colleagues, including the supervisor, prior to the ``live'' talk.

Theses

The final thesis is somewhat different from the rest of the written work produced during a candidacy; it is the work primarily of the student, and authorship is sole. This raises difficult issues for both student and supervisor. The student must clearly indicate which of the original ideas were provided by the supervisor at the commencement of the project, and which are claimed as the result of the project itself. The supervisor is often torn between a desire to improve the quality of the thesis, and the need for the student to write their own work. The degree to which supervisors proofread and correct the detail of the thesis is variable, but supervisors should remember that examiners will be scornful of poorly presented work, and that the scorn will extend to the supervisor as well as the student. Students who know that they have difficulty with written expression should consider using (and paying for privately) the services of a professional proofreader.

One reasonable requirement is that a supervisor not be expected to read more than two drafts of any particular chapter. Students should also appreciate that providing critical comment can take time and should plan their production schedule accordingly so that they do not further refine some section while the supervisor believes it to be ``frozen''. It is annoying to spend a week reading a thesis chapter in detail marking grammatical and presentational changes, only to be told, upon returning it to the student, to ``never mind, I have just printed another draft of that chapter for you with new results''. For their part, supervisors should read material in a timely manner--one week to read a thesis chapter is reasonable, one month is not.

When the thesis is complete, the supervisor and Head of Department are required to sign a declaration that the thesis is ready to be sent for examination. This is an important requirement, and should not be taken lightly. Students should not dismiss suggestions from their supervisor as being nitpicky, or too demanding; they may enter into debate as to the need for suggested changes, but should not arbitrarily ignore such requests.

At first submission theses may usually be in temporary bindings. Formatting requirements may include restrictions on word or page counts, the width of page borders, the amount of interline spacing, etc. The details of these requirements change from time to time and from degree to degree, and it is important that students seek information from the School of Graduate Studies well before the proposed submission date. Finding out such information is the responsibility of the student, not the supervisor.

Some scholarships provide for reimbursement of thesis expenses, and sometimes even for professional proofreading. Students on scholarships should be sure to determine the level of such reimbursement, and any stipulated conditions that may be attached. Departmental facilities may be used for the preparation and printing of theses, but students should note that in some cases final submitted theses should be on acid-free or other special paper types, and the cost of this paper must be met by the student. The student is also responsible for binding costs.

There is a wide range of written material available to help the thesis writing task, and students should actively seek such material by visiting the relevant Faculty Office, the School of Graduate Studies, and the Postgraduate Union. A guide used in the marking of M.Sc. theses is attached to the print version of this document.

Thesis awards

The University sponsors an award for a thesis of ``outstanding'' merit, with support for publication of the thesis through the Melbourne University Press. For application details, contact the School of Graduate Studies.

The University also provides three ``Chancellor's Medals'' annually for theses of outstanding quality. For details, contact the School of Graduate Studies.

The Computer Science Association (CSA, the sponsor of the annual Australasian Computer Science Conference) funds an award for the ``best Ph.D. thesis''. Rao Kotagiri (rao) has in the past been on the panel of this award; for details contact him.

Research ethics

The University policy can be viewed at

  http://www.research.unimelb.edu.au/admin/res.conduct/code.html.

Intellectual property rights

The University policy can be viewed at

  http://www.research.unimelb.edu.au/ridg/ip/.

Reviewing

Postgraduate students should be prepared to undertake reviewing duties. This will initially be with the advice and input of their supervisor while the necessary skills (and, sometimes, tact!) are being assimilated; but, by the end of their candidature, students should be confident to undertake this task in their own right. If a typical paper has two authors and three reviewers, then authors must expect to review more papers than they write. Reviewing is an essential, but completely unglamorous, component of the research process. Ian Parberry has written a useful guide to the reviewing process, see

http://hercule.csci.unt.edu/ian/guides/guides.html.


Formal stages

Application

Application forms for postgraduate degrees are available from the departmental office, from the relevant faculty office, or from the School of Graduate Studies. Applications from permanent residents should be lodged with the departmental office, and will be accepted and processed at any time during the year. Students seeking scholarships should note that a postgraduate application should be lodged by the time the scholarship application is lodged; the main close-off date for Australian resident scholarships (APA's and resident MRS) is usually around the end of October each year. It is also possible to apply for a bridging MRS at other times of the year, but there are relatively few of these offered and, as a rule of thumb, they are only available to students who would clearly have been awarded an APA or a MRS in the main round.

Overseas students should apply through the International Office; the closing date for overseas postgraduate research scholarships (IPRSs) is usually in mid September. Overseas students may also be eligible for MIRS/MIFRS scholarships. For details of scholarships, closing dates, and conditions, prospective applicants (including currently enrolled postgraduates) are urged to seek definitive information from the SGS well before the anticipated closing dates. Start by visiting http://www.sgs.unimelb.edu.au/pgstudy/ and http://www.services.unimelb.edu.au/scholarships/.

Selection

Applications for entry and for conversion are considered by the departmental Research Postgraduate Selection Committee, at the time of writing Alistair Moffat, Zoltan Somogyi, Harald Søndergaard, and Leon Sterling. Taken into account are the previous record of undergraduate study; level and quality of prior postgraduate study; publications; relevant work experience; the relationship between the proposed project and the research interests of the department; the capacity of the staff involved in the proposed area to supervise further postgraduates; and the endorsement provided by the potential supervisor, if one has been arranged. The latter is especially helpful in considering applications: if the committee can see that a potential supervisor is interested in the student and prepared to endorse the project, acceptance is much more likely.

Students (and staff) should be aware that individual staff members may not ``accept'' students or agree to supervise them; they may only discuss projects and endorse an application. Acceptance is made at the Faculty level, after the Head of Department makes a recommendation to the Faculty (or SGS, or International Office). This misunderstanding has at times led to difficulty; no student may commence work in the department until an application has been fully processed through the appropriate channels, irrespective of whether or not a tentative supervision agreement has been reached with a staff member.

Enrolment

Once accepted, the relevant Faculty will communicate with the student in regard to enrolment formalities. Queries with regard to these formalities should be made to the appropriate governing authority: The Faculty of Engineering for M.Comp.Sc. and M.Eng.Sc. students, the Faculty of Science for M.Sc. students, the School of Graduate Studies for Ph.D. students, and the International Office for all overseas students. Research degrees may be commenced at any stage during the year, although it is expected that there will be an influx of new students in February and March.

Advisory committees

All students enrolled in research degrees have an advisory committee consisting of their supervisor and at least one other academic adviser. The purpose of these committees is to assist and monitor postgraduate students' studies.

A Ph.D. student's advisory committee comprises the student's supervisor and two other academics. A masters student's advisory committee comprises the student's supervisor and one other academic. Masters students who already have two supervisors do not need another academic adviser. Ph.D. students who already have two supervisors need only one other academic adviser. In each case, the supervisor is the chair of the committee.

Students, in consultation with their supervisor, should approach suitable staff after they commence their study. The committee members need not be within the same speciality as the student and supervisor; the intention is that they be available to provide general procedural input, and a safeguard against breakdown of the student-supervisor relationship. Once finalised, details of the proposed arrangement should be lodged with the office for approval by the postgraduate committee.

It is important to stress that advisory committees supplement the well established procedures currently in place for the management of masters and Ph.D. candidatures. The committees do not reduce the importance of the supervisor-student relationship, which the department considers to be key to all masters and Ph.D. candidatures. The student's supervisor remains as the student's main adviser and first point of contact on all matters regarding the student's research programme and the student's interaction with the department. The Head of Department is ultimately responsible to the School of Graduate Studies and the University for the candidature of all graduate students in the department.

Progress meetings

Ph.D. and masters students (part-time and full-time) will be required to meet with their advisory committee every six months during the first year of candidature, and at least every twelve months after that. At this time, a standard form, which will summarise the student's progress, will be signed by the student and the committee and kept for departmental records. The advisory committee may also be required to meet at other times, as appropriate. For example, masters students applying for conversion to Ph.D. enrolment should discuss their application with their advisory committee prior to lodging their application (see the next paragraph).

Conversion

Unless they have already completed a substantial research degree (usually supported by publications in appropriate conferences or journals) students will, in the first instance, be accepted as masters level candidates. After nine months of enrolment students may then apply for their enrolment to be converted to confirmed Ph.D. candidature, which, if approved, is normally backdated to the date of masters enrolment.

Conversion/confirmation is not a formality. You will need to prepare an application and arrange, together with your supervisor, a time for your advisory/confirmation committee to meet with you. It is a good idea to get the application form after 6 months, to get a better understanding of the requirements.

Your application will be assessed by your Advisory Committee against the same criteria as new Ph.D. applications, and the support of the supervisor is required. The application must include a progress report of about 3000 words written by you. The report should include

  1. A clear definition of the problem you are trying to solve;
  2. An explanation of why the problem is important;
  3. A comprehensive literature survey describing all relevant work so far related to your research problem, placing your work in the context of others' and describing how your work goes beyond previous work;
  4. Research results so far - preferably with reference to publications by you or to papers submitted for publication.
  5. Future research plan - investigations, experiments and writing that you plan to do, with rough time-lines.
  6. A 2-3 page summary of the above. The summary will be sent to the School of Graduate Studies.
If conversion is to be recommended by the Head of Department, the advisory committee will be required to state that you have made good progress, and that the project is capable of leading to the award of a Ph.D.

Conversion should not be regarded as a method for students to avoid the need to face up to a lack of progress in a masters degree during their first year of candidature. Most years there are cases of rejected confirmation applications, so you need to have a plan in place for the completion of your Masters program, in case conversion is not approved.

Confirmation

Students who enrol directly into the Ph.D. degree will be granted probationary candidature initially. After nine months of enrolment they must apply to have their candidature confirmed. This is effectively the same process as conversion from masters to Ph.D. candidature, and similar standards will be applied. Ph.D. students who do not apply for confirmation will have their enrolment terminated.

For confirmation you will be required to give a postgraduate seminar. This must be advertised at least 2 weeks in advance and explicitly advertised as a confirmation seminar. You should make sure that your advisory committee can attend.

Length of candidature

Students should be aware that the University is becoming increasingly strict about the duration of research degrees. Extension beyond the prescribed time period is possible, but by no means automatic, and will requires a reason more convincing than ``I need more time''.

Scholarship holders in particular should be aware of the great difficulties they will face should they prolong their candidature beyond the life of their funding.

Students are thus urged to regularly remind themselves of their expected completion date, to read the regulations for their degree (copies are available in the departmental office), and to memorise the date that their scholarship expires.

Normal duration of a Ph.D. is three years, with one (and in exceptional cases, two) six month extension possible; the M.Sc. is a 12 month degree with an absolute maximum of 24 months; and the M.Eng.Sc. is a 12 month degree, with an absolute maximum of 18 months. Extensions beyond these limits will normally only be granted on medical grounds where extended periods of incapacity can be proven. All of these times should be doubled for part-time candidates. Applications for extension must be in writing, and require the endorsement of both the supervisor and the postgraduate coordinator. If the end of a specified candidature is reached without such application being received the candidature will automatically lapse.

Seminars

All postgraduate students are required to present a seminar every twelve months of enrolment. Students who deliver public ``practise talks'' of upcoming conference presentations may count that as their annual seminar. Usually these presentations are given in the Friday series of post-graduate seminars. All postgaduate seminars are announced at http://www.cs.mu.oz.au/pgrad/seminars/.

Thesis examination

Towards the end of each candidature the administering faculty will request that the department supply the names of examiners.

The examination committee for masters theses normally consists of two examiners, one of whom may be from inside the Department (but not the supervisor) and one external examiner who must be from outside the department. In the Department of Computer Science and Software Engineering the usual practice is to appoint two examiners from outside the Department. External examiners may be in Australia, or may be overseas. Students may often informally discuss potential examiners with their supervisor, but final responsibility for selecting an examination committee rests with the Head of Department. There is no requirement or provision for oral examination or thesis defence.

The examination committee for Ph.D. theses consists of three examiners. The first will normally be an overseas expert in the subject area of the thesis. The second examiner is required to be outside the University, but not necessarily outside Australia. These two examiners are first asked to provide reports on the thesis. In the event of the examiners returning recommendations that differ markedly, the third examiner is called in to arbitrate. This third examiner is, however, selected at the same time as the first two examiners, and again must have no connection with the University. Students are invited to submit a list of people (with reasons) that they would prefer not be asked to examine their thesis, but the actual identity of the selected examiners is kept confidential. As for masters level theses, there is no provision for oral examination of the candidate.

Once the reports have been received and an outcome decided, copies of the reports are given to the candidate, and if the recommendation is to accept the thesis, the candidate will be invited to submit a final bound version of their thesis. At this time the candidate will also be advised either of the names of the examiners, or, if the examiners do not wish their names divulged, of this fact.

Part-time candidature

In the experience of the department it is very difficult for part-time candidates to undertake research degrees, and the nature of the proposed candidature is taken into account during the selection process. Nevertheless, there are also situations in which part-time candidate is appropriate, or when conversion from full-time candidature is necessary. Part-time students should be especially aware of the need to make steady progress in their investigation and to keep in good contact with their supervisor.

Social interaction

Postgraduate students are expected to take the initiative in ensuring that the department has an active social life, and that staff are occasionally extracted from their offices for a bit of frivolity. There are currently a number of semi-regular events of this nature. For an up-to-date account, check out http://www.cs.mu.oz.au/pgrad/pgwiki/.

Postgraduate tea/lunch

Most Fridays at 11:00 there is a postgraduate morning tea in the level 4 staff room. Matters of general interest will often be discussed, and it is useful for as many students as possible to attend. After morning tea there is usually a postgraduate seminar, at 12. Also, at irregular intervals various groups of students (plus hangers on) go to various places to eat various foodstuffs. This is usually advertised through the cs-postgrads mailing list.

Lunchtime barbecues

This event takes place roughly one or two months (less often in winter), usually on a Friday lunchtime, on the patio on level five. It is organised by postgrads; volunteering to be one of the ``barbee team'' is a sure way of making some contacts. A nominal fee is charged to cover food-related costs. Upcoming events are advertised via electronic mail. The barbecue unit is the property of the department, and may be used by any interested group.

Tea rooms

Research postgraduate students will find tea, coffee, and milk in the Staff Room on level 4. Students must provide their own cups; please do not ``borrow'' other people's cups from the various tearooms, no matter how brief the intended loan. Postgraduate students can also use the microwave ovens in the small tearooms.

School of Graduate Studies

The SGS also organises social events for research students. Details of these will appear on notice-boards from time to time.

Links are provided to university regulations and authoritative university web sites.
